Entry.JapaneseText: [VARIABLE]
Entry.EnglishText: [VARIABLE]

Entry.JapaneseText: おじいさん
Entry.EnglishText: Old Man

Entry.JapaneseText: <Tytree>
Entry.EnglishText: <Tytree>

Entry.JapaneseText: <Eugene>
Entry.EnglishText: <Eugene>

Entry.JapaneseText: <Veigue>
Entry.EnglishText: <Veigue>

Entry.JapaneseText: <Hilda>
Entry.EnglishText: <Hilda>

Entry.JapaneseText: おばあさん
Entry.EnglishText: Old Woman

Entry.JapaneseText: <Agarte>
Entry.EnglishText: <Agarte>

Entry.JapaneseText: <Mao>
Entry.EnglishText: <Mao>

Entry.JapaneseText: select
Entry.EnglishText: Select

Entry.JapaneseText: モクラド村
Entry.EnglishText: Mocrado Village

Entry.JapaneseText: モクラド村・民家
Entry.EnglishText: Mocrado Village - Residence

Entry.JapaneseText: 民家
Entry.EnglishText: Residence

Entry.JapaneseText: あんたら…… ヒューマとガジュマなのに、 一緒って事は……
Entry.EnglishText: In spite of being different races, you're traveling together...

Entry.JapaneseText: 何か文句でもあんのか？ ……ったく…… どこへ行ってもこれだ……
Entry.EnglishText: Yeah, you have a problem with that?! Tch, everywhere you go, I swear...

Entry.JapaneseText: 違う、そういう事じゃない、 この村に来るのはわけありの者が多い。 あんたらもそうかと思ってな……
Entry.EnglishText: No, that's not what I meant. It's just that most who come to this village tend to do so for a specific reason. I thought that might be the case for you folks as well.

Entry.JapaneseText: いえ、私たちは 人を探しに来たのです。
Entry.EnglishText: Actually, we're looking for someone.

Entry.JapaneseText: 十年ほど前、占い師がこの村に 向かったそうなのですが…… 心当たりはありませんか？
Entry.EnglishText: We were told that a fortune teller apparently came to this village around ten years ago. Would you happen to know anything about her?

Entry.JapaneseText: ……占い師？ ナイラさんの事かな？
Entry.EnglishText: A fortune teller? Well, that sounds like Nayla.

Entry.JapaneseText: ナイラ…… その人は、まだこの村に？
Entry.EnglishText: Nayla, is it? Does she still live here?

Entry.JapaneseText: うむ、装備品屋の隣が、 ナイラさんの家だよ。
Entry.EnglishText: She does. Her house is right next to the equipment shop.

Entry.JapaneseText: ……その人は……どんな人？
Entry.EnglishText: Well... What is she like?

Entry.JapaneseText: ……笑顔を忘れたような…… 哀しい瞳をした人だ……
Entry.EnglishText: Sorrow is always reflected in her eyes... It's as though she's forgotten what happiness is.

Entry.JapaneseText: ナイラさんの事で、 聞きたい事がある……
Entry.EnglishText: There's something we'd like to ask you about Nayla.

Entry.JapaneseText: ナイラさんの事で……？
Entry.EnglishText: What about her?

Entry.JapaneseText: そう……あなたが ナイラさんの娘さん……
Entry.EnglishText: Ah, so you're her daughter.

Entry.JapaneseText: そう言えば一度だけ、 ナイラさんと ゆっくり話した事があるわ……
Entry.EnglishText: Come to think of it, we did have a rather interesting heart-to-heart once.

Entry.JapaneseText: あの人は、旦那さんを亡くされた後、 ずっとひとりで、国じゅうを 旅していたんですって……
Entry.EnglishText: After her husband passed away, Nayla roamed The Kingdom on her own...

Entry.JapaneseText: 奪われた娘さんを…… そう……あなたを探すためにね……
Entry.EnglishText: ...In search of the daughter who was stolen away from her. She had been looking for you.

Entry.JapaneseText: ……奪われた娘……!?
Entry.EnglishText: ...Stolen?!

Entry.JapaneseText: 結局、あなたは見つからず、 ナイラさんはこの村に来たの。 そして、あなたの幸せを祈る事に したんですって……
Entry.EnglishText: Eventually, she settled here in this village after failing to find you. She told me that she was praying for your happiness...

Entry.JapaneseText: それに、もしもあなたが 行き場を失うような事があれば、 きっとこの村に来るだろうって……
Entry.EnglishText: She strongly believed that if you were ever without a place to call home, you would somehow find your way here.

Entry.JapaneseText: その時に、 すれ違いにならないようにって、 ナイラさんはめったに家から出ないのよ。
Entry.EnglishText: So that she wouldn't miss you when that time eventually came, she rarely left her home.

Entry.JapaneseText: ……そんなの、同情を買うために あの人が考えた作り話だわ!! だって……
Entry.EnglishText: ...She must have made up that story so that you would feel sorry for her!

Entry.JapaneseText: だって、 私は捨てられたんだもの！
Entry.EnglishText: I wasn't abducted, I was abandoned!

Entry.JapaneseText: <Hilda>さん……！
Entry.EnglishText: <Hilda>...

Entry.JapaneseText: ……本当の事は私にはわからない…… でも、これだけは信じてあげて。
Entry.EnglishText: Admittedly, I don't know what actually happened. However, I want you to believe what I am about to tell you.

Entry.JapaneseText: ナイラさんは…… あなたのお母さんは、 心の底からあなたを愛してるわ。
Entry.EnglishText: Your mother... She loves you from the bottom of her heart.

Entry.JapaneseText: ねえ、<Hilda>…… もう一度、お母さんのところに 行ってみようよ？
Entry.EnglishText: Hey, <Hilda>... Why don't we try seeing your mother just one last time?

Entry.JapaneseText: ……<Hilda>さん、ナイラさんは あなたの事を本当に愛してた……
Entry.EnglishText: ...Miss <Hilda>, Miss Nayla truly loved you...

Entry.JapaneseText: そのあなたを守る事が できたんですもの、きっと 後悔なんてしてないはずよ。
Entry.EnglishText: I'm sure she has no regrets because she was able to protect you.

Entry.JapaneseText: あなたも悔いのない人生を 生きてちょうだいね……
Entry.EnglishText: I hope that you too can live your life without regrets...

Entry.JapaneseText: 皆さん、ナイラさんの分まで <Hilda>さんとなかよくして くださいね
Entry.EnglishText: Everyone, please be a good friend to Miss <Hilda>, for Nayla's sake.

Entry.JapaneseText: <Hilda>さん、 いつでも困った事があったら、 この村に来てください。
Entry.EnglishText: Miss <Hilda>, if you're ever in any trouble, feel free to come visit.

Entry.JapaneseText: おじいさんの昔話は 聞かれましたか？
Entry.EnglishText: Have you been listening to that old man's stories?

Entry.JapaneseText: ある事、ない事、言うお人ですから、 話半分で聞いておいてくださいな。
Entry.EnglishText: He tends to blur the line between truth and fiction, so be sure take his stories with a grain of salt.
Entry.Notes: Could be truths and lies, but I'm not sure if he's deliberately lying out of malice or if it could just be a mistake or playful lying.

Entry.JapaneseText: この音…… 気のせいじゃないのね…… とても怖いわね……
Entry.EnglishText: This sound... It's not just my imagination... How terrifying...

Entry.JapaneseText: おじいさんの昔話は 聞かれましたか？
Entry.EnglishText: Have you been listening to that old man's stories?

Entry.JapaneseText: ある事、ない事、言うお人ですから、 話半分で聞いておいてくださいな。
Entry.EnglishText: He tends to blur the line between truth and fiction, so be sure take his stories with a grain of salt.
Entry.Notes: Could be truths and lies, but I'm not sure if he's deliberately lying out of malice or if it could just be a mistake or playful lying.

Entry.JapaneseText: <Hilda>さんや…… お母さんは強い人じゃった…… あんたも強く生きるんじゃよ。
Entry.EnglishText: Miss <Hilda>... Your mother was strong... You must also be strong like she was.

Entry.JapaneseText: ワシはその昔、 カレギアの軍人じゃった……
Entry.EnglishText: In the past, I served Callegea as a knight...

Entry.JapaneseText: ナイラさんの代わりに ワシが……ワシが……
Entry.EnglishText: On behalf of Miss Nayla, I'll...I'll...

Entry.JapaneseText: この村に何かがあれば、 ワシが……ワシが守る！ 元カレギア軍人の誇りにかけて！
Entry.EnglishText: I'll protect this village...no matter what happens! I stake it on my pride as an ex-Callegean knight!

Entry.JapaneseText: あんた、軍人じゃろ？ ワシもその昔、カレギア軍に いた事があったんじゃ。
Entry.EnglishText: You're a soldier, aren't you? I was once in the Callegean army, too.

Entry.JapaneseText: ここで会ったのも何かの縁じゃ。 ワシが昔使ってた、槍をやろう。
Entry.EnglishText: It's quite a lucky coincidence that we met. Let me give you my old spear.

Entry.JapaneseText: 大切に使えば、 七代先まで使えるぞ。 家宝にしてくれよ。
Entry.EnglishText: If you take good care of it, it'll last you at least seven generations. Keep it as an heirloom.

Entry.JapaneseText: その昔、ワシは勇猛果敢な カレギア軍人じゃった。
Entry.EnglishText: Once upon a time, I served as a brave and valiant Callegean knight.

Entry.JapaneseText: ところが、うちのばあさんと 恋に落ちてな。
Entry.EnglishText: But then I fell in love with that old lady over there.

Entry.JapaneseText: それで、禁断の逃避行…… 脱走兵っちゅーわけじゃ。 まあ、もう時効じゃがな。
Entry.EnglishText: As a result, we ended up in a forbidden relationship and eloped...and I ended up deserting the army. But in any case, it's been long past the statute of limitations.

Entry.JapaneseText: ワシはその昔、 カレギア軍人じゃった。 勇猛さではワシの右に出る者は おらんかった。
Entry.EnglishText: A long time ago, I served as a Callegean knight. No one could match my bravery.

Entry.JapaneseText: それがどうして こんなところにいるかって？
Entry.EnglishText: So why is it that I'm now here, you ask?

Entry.JapaneseText: ほっほっほ…… 年寄りには色々あるんじゃ……
Entry.EnglishText: Ho! Ho! Ho! Well, there's a lot to be said about older people...

Entry.JapaneseText: <speed:0><scale:140>休憩しますか？ はい いいえ
Entry.EnglishText: <speed:0><scale:140>Would you like to rest? Yes No

Entry.JapaneseText: <speed:0>『ホウキとチリトリ』 掃除をするための道具。 全世界共通のごくありふれたもの。
Entry.EnglishText: <speed:0>- Brooms and Dustbins - Tools that are used for cleaning. they are common tools used all over the world.

Entry.JapaneseText: 掃除は苦手……だなあ……
Entry.EnglishText: Ugh... I'm bad at chores...

Entry.JapaneseText: 掃除ならおれに まかせとけってんだ！
Entry.EnglishText: When it comes to keeping floors dust free, you can count on me!

Entry.JapaneseText: <speed:0>『壁際に置いてあるもの』 食材を始め、 本や草花まで飾られており、 物置なのか飾り棚なのか わからない状態になっている。
Entry.EnglishText: <speed:0>- Items on the Shelf - The lineup of items begins with ingredients, followed by books, and then flowers. It's hard to tell whether it's a storage closet or a display case.

Entry.JapaneseText: <speed:0>『手紙』 いろいろなところへ 送ろうと書かれた手紙。 結局、出されずじまいに なっている。
Entry.EnglishText: <speed:0>- Letters - There are various letters written here that were originally meant to be sent out. But in the end, they never were.

Entry.JapaneseText: <speed:0>『犬の絵』 おじいさんとおばあさんが 我が子のように可愛がっていた 愛犬ビクトールの絵。 今はもう亡くなっている。
Entry.EnglishText: <speed:0>- Picture of a Dog - This is a painting of Viktor, the beloved dog that the Old Man and Woman cherished as if he were their child. He has long since passed away.
